name: Black documentary and truth telling
description: Essie Coffey was a trailblazer of Indigenous filmmaking, being the first Aboriginal woman to direct a documentary. The film spotlights the outspoken voice Coffey utilised to convey the realities faced by Aboriginal people and to encourage resistance to assimilation.

key_work.title: My Survival as an Aboriginal
key_work.credit_line:
From the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia – NFSA Restores Collection
Courtesy Ballad Films
key_work.brief_description:
“I wanted to show that we have and will continue to survive white invasion.”

Essie Coffey’s camera zooms in on the thin lips of a white teacher telling a class of Aboriginal students that Captain Cook ‘discovered’ Australia. The students gaze back, their eyes becoming the focus, fed up with the narratives that erase the true history of invasion and Aboriginal sovereignty taught in schools.

My Survival as an Aboriginal shows the reality of life for Essie’s community in Brewarrina, while simultaneously calling into question the fantasies perpetuated by non-Indigenous voyeurs; she staunchly refused to assimilate.

Essie pushed boundaries in her everyday life and in her artmaking. She made this uncompromising documentary film in 1978 at a time when opportunities for women filmmakers were few and far between, let alone for Indigenous women filmmakers.

By recording her own life and amplifying her voice, Essie gave future generations of First Nations truthtellers their own voice, inspiring a movement of films that showed Aboriginal life in a way that challenged racism and injustice, and imagine a better future unbound from white control.

end.title: Black Man's Houses
end.creator_credit: Steve Thomas and Open Channel Co-Operative
end.brief_description: Black Man’s Houses tells a dramatic story of the quest by Aboriginal people to reclaim the graves of their ancestors, who were exiled at Wybalenna on Flinders Island by the Van Diemen’s Land government, against a background of racism and denial.

links.description: Black Man’s Houses is a documentary that captures the struggle for recognition of Tasmanian Aboriginal people in their fight to reclaim the unmarked graves of their Ancestors who were removed from their lands and taken to Wybalenna on Flinders Island.

end.title: Who killed Malcolm Smith?
end.creator_credit: Caroline Sherwood, Nicholas Adler, Film Australia and Titus Films
end.brief_description: On December 29, 1982 Malcolm Smith killed himself in prison. Richard Frankland, a commissioner for the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody revisits friends and family to find out circumstances of his death and First Peoples in custody generally.

links.description: This documentary investigates what happened to Malcolm Smith, an Aboriginal man who died while incarcerated. Director Richard Frankland was an Investigator for the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody from 1987–91, which influenced production of this film in 1992.

start.title: Prison Songs

end.title: No way to forget
end.brief_description: Richard Frankland’s powerful short film based on his experiences as a lawyer on the Royal Commission on Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. A young Koorie man travelling the lonely highways of the Australian outback reflects on the tragic experiences of Aboriginal people in Australian prisons.

links.description: This 1996 short film is based off Frankland’s experiences investigating the Royal Commission. The lead character Shane drives through the night and is haunted by flashbacks of prison cells and grieving family members he has witnessed on the job.
